degree_multipliers.rationale: Activists and volunteers are natural social hubs — they organize, attend events, and build broad community networks across many contacts.
Self-employed individuals must build and maintain wide professional networks (clients, vendors, collaborators) to sustain their business.
Heavy social media users accumulate many online connections that translate to broader social influence and network size.
Managers and professionals interact with many colleagues, clients, and stakeholders as part of their daily work.
Full-time workers have consistent daily workplace interactions that generate many weak and strong ties.
Married individuals tend to have larger combined social networks, including in-laws, couple-friends, and shared community connections.
Parents with children form connections through schools, sports, playdates, and parenting communities, significantly expanding their social networks.

edge_type_rules.name: household_member
edge_type_rules.description: Two agents share the same household — domestic partners, roommates, or family members living together.

edge_type_rules.name: local_political_ally
edge_type_rules.condition: a_state == b_state and a_political_affiliation == b_political_affiliation and a_urban_rural == b_urban_rural
edge_type_rules.description: Same state, same community type, and same political affiliation — likely connected through local political organizations, civic groups, or partisan social circles.

edge_type_rules.name: faith_community
edge_type_rules.condition: a_state == b_state and a_religious_affiliation == b_religious_affiliation and a_religious_affiliation != "None/Unaffiliated"
edge_type_rules.description: Same state and same religious affiliation (non-secular) — connected through a shared church, mosque, synagogue, or other faith community.

edge_type_rules.name: local_community
edge_type_rules.description: Same state and same urban/rural setting — general local community ties such as neighbors, local organizations, or shared venues.

edge_type_rules.name: political_echo_chamber
edge_type_rules.description: Same political affiliation and same media consumption lean — connected through shared online communities, social media groups, or national partisan networks.

edge_type_rules.name: weak_tie
edge_type_rules.description: Shared social media platform — loose online connections through common digital spaces, with no strong real-world anchor.

influence_factors.description: Higher education level confers social credibility and perceived expertise, making more educated individuals more influential in discussions about policy and current events.

influence_factors.levels: {"Rarely/Never votes": 1, "Votes sometimes": 2, "Votes regularly": 3, "Actively volunteers or campaigns": 4}
influence_factors.description: More civically engaged individuals — especially those who actively campaign or volunteer — are more influential opinion leaders in their communities.
Higher income correlates with social status, access to information, and perceived authority, creating asymmetric influence in social interactions.
Individuals who spend more time on social media disseminate more content, interact with more people, and have outsized influence on the information environment of their network.
